subject: AI
title: AI in Healthcare
description: Where AI helps doctors and where it falls short.

hook.text: An AI spots a tumor on a scan that three radiologists missed. It also confidently flags a shadow as cancer when it's just an artifact. Both happen.

buildup.text: Medical AI assists in diagnostics (reading scans, pathology slides), drug discovery (screening molecules), and administrative tasks (coding billing records).

discovery.text: In dermatology, AI models match or exceed dermatologists at classifying skin lesions â€” but only on populations well-represented in the training data.

twist.text: FDA-cleared doesn't mean perfect. Regulations test safety, but real-world performance can differ from clinical trials â€” especially with different patient demographics.

climax.text: AI in healthcare works best as a second opinion, not a replacement. The doctor uses AI to catch what they might miss; the doctor catches what AI gets wrong.

punchline.text: AI + doctor beats AI alone and doctor alone. That's the sweet spot.

quiz.question: How is medical AI best used currently?
options: As a complete replacement for doctors
As a second opinion alongside physicians
